Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I (COVID-19): Developing a comprehensive and customizable science courseware grounded in evidence-based teaching and learning practices
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to advance the state of practice of STEM courses. Certain techniques, known as evidence-based teaching (EBT), can improve performance for all STEM learners and narrow the achievement gaps, but 80% of STEM classrooms are still primarily lecture-based. This project will develop a digital course design tool enabling an instructor to quickly create and implement an exciting STEM course course. It will create and scale a plug-and-play library of high-quality assessment items and instructional resources in a way that instructors find empowering, easy to use, and valuable. This will be valuable during a period of remote learning, such as that created by the social distancing of the COVID-19 situation.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will support the development and testing of a system to distribute EBT course structure and content at scale. Active learning and high-structure courses produce better outcomes, and therefore this project focuses on dissemination of EBT curricula and course structures. The research objectives are to automate course design, and explore user requirements for the system to scale, and produce real-time feedback on student performance.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In Phase I, Codon Learning conducted research and development of our courseware application, Design-to-Align (D2A). D2A enables postsecondary instructors to design and teach courses using inclusive evidence-based teaching practices including backward course design, active learning, and frequent formative assessment with feedback‒practices that have been empirically shown to boost student learning, improve student retention, and bridge pervasive representation gaps in STEM (Eddy & Hogan, 2014; Freeman et al., 2011, 2014; Theobald et al., 2020).

Less than half of the students who enter college intending to major in a STEM field will complete a STEM degree (PCAST, 2012). Students from historically underserved groups leave STEM at much higher rates than their majority peers (Asai, 2020). The significant and persistent underrepresentation of certain students in STEM degree programs is inequitable and results in a loss of talent in STEM fields (Asai & Bauerle, 2016). This lack of retention has been exacerbated by the COVID-19 pandemic, which has caused enrollments to plummet, especially with first-year students (New York Times, 2020). 

Despite ongoing calls for reform and unequivocal evidence supporting practices that could reverse these trends, instructors have been slow to change. The have encountered significant barriers have encountered significant barriers to change, including a lack of time needed to prepare class materials, lack of access to evidence-based teaching materials, and lack of professional development needed to implement evidence-based teaching practices (Bathgate et al, 2019; Brownell & Tanner, 2012; Shadle, Marker, & Earl, 2017). Thus, most instructors employ less effective, instructor-centered teaching strategies similar to those they experienced as students (Grunspan, Kline, & Brownell, 2018; Stains et al., 2018).

Thus, our challenge is to reduce instructor barriers to evidence-based teaching by building a user interface and suite of digital content that instructors find empowering, easy to use, and valuable. Our primary objective for Phase I was to design a technology tool that would make evidence-based teaching feel comfortable and valuable to instructors. To achieve this objective, we conducted in-depth customer discovery interviews to identify relevant instructor challenges, consulted with expert STEM educators to design prototypes, and performed iterative rounds of prototyping and user testing to shape D2A. 

The result was an intuitive and streamlined workflow and interface that instructors found clean and easy to use. We feel confident that D2A solves instructors' pain points and enables them to design STEM courses using the evidence-based practices that will retain and advance the students we need to propel the future STEM workforce. We discovered that significant intellectual merit lies in the rich sets of student learning data that are generated by a course designed using D2A. These data enable instructors to pinpoint challenging concepts and intervene when students are struggling before it's too late. Moreover, these learning data may prove even more useful for students to develop metacognitive awareness and remediate their own gaps in knowledge. Future research and development will explore the immense potential of the learning data in the student-facing side of our application.

In summary, our courseware platform will catalyze the use of inclusive evidence-based practices that have been empirically shown to improve learning outcomes and retention rates for STEM students from all backgrounds. These efforts support the NSF goals of developing an American STEM workforce that is globally competitive through improved undergraduate STEM education and instruction and expanding participation of women and individuals from underrepresented groups in STEM.
